trans-unit.source: Filter
trans-unit.target: Filter

trans-unit.source: Data Transformation / Filter
trans-unit.target: Data Transformation / Filter

trans-unit.source: Filters are used to transform data during preprocessing to enhance the clarity of the signal used for machine learning.
trans-unit.target: Filters are used to transform data during preprocessing to enhance the clarity of the signal used for machine learning.

trans-unit.source: The filters in Azure Machine Learning Studio (Studio) can be used to:
trans-unit.target: The filters in Azure Machine Learning Studio (Studio) can be used to:

trans-unit.source: Analyze interference or artifacts in telemetry signals.
trans-unit.target: Analyze interference or artifacts in telemetry signals.

trans-unit.source: Perform tasks such as image recognition and speech recognition.
trans-unit.target: Perform tasks such as image recognition and speech recognition.

trans-unit.source: Detect trends or remove seasonal effects in noisy sales or economic data.
trans-unit.target: Detect trends or remove seasonal effects in noisy sales or economic data.

trans-unit.source: The filter modules in Azure Machine Learning Studio provide easy access to well researched algorithms that are used to mathematically transform waveform data.
trans-unit.target: The filter modules in Azure Machine Learning Studio provide easy access to well researched algorithms that are used to mathematically transform waveform data.

trans-unit.source: You can also create a custom filter if you have already determined the correct coefficients to apply to your data.
trans-unit.target: You can also create a custom filter if you have already determined the correct coefficients to apply to your data.

trans-unit.source: Need to filter data from a dataset or remove missing values?
trans-unit.target: Need to filter data from a dataset or remove missing values?

trans-unit.source: Use these modules instead:
trans-unit.target: Use these modules instead:

trans-unit.source: Use this module to remove missing values or replace missing values with placeholders.
trans-unit.target: Use this module to remove missing values or replace missing values with placeholders.

trans-unit.source: Use this module to divide or filter your dataset by criteria such as a range of dates, a specific value, or regular expressions.
trans-unit.target: Use this module to divide or filter your dataset by criteria such as a range of dates, a specific value, or regular expressions.

trans-unit.source: Use this module to set a range and keep only the values within that range.
trans-unit.target: Use this module to set a range and keep only the values within that range.

trans-unit.source: What is a Filter?
trans-unit.target: What is a Filter?

trans-unit.source: The filters in Azure Machine Learning Studio are based on filters developed for signal processing technology.
trans-unit.target: The filters in Azure Machine Learning Studio are based on filters developed for signal processing technology.

trans-unit.source: Just as a filter can be attached to a camera to compensate for lighting or create special effects, you can apply a filter to the data used for machine learning, to improve the clarity of a signal, to capture interesting characteristics, or to reduce noise.
trans-unit.target: Just as a filter can be attached to a camera to compensate for lighting or create special effects, you can apply a filter to the data used for machine learning, to improve the clarity of a signal, to capture interesting characteristics, or to reduce noise.

trans-unit.source: The ideal filter would eliminate all noise and have uniform sensitivity for the desired signal, but designing even a pretty good filter might take many iterations or combinations of techniques.
trans-unit.target: The ideal filter would eliminate all noise and have uniform sensitivity for the desired signal, but designing even a pretty good filter might take many iterations or combinations of techniques.

trans-unit.source: If you succeed in designing an effective filter, consider saving the filter so that you can reuse it when transforming new data.
trans-unit.target: If you succeed in designing an effective filter, consider saving the filter so that you can reuse it when transforming new data.

trans-unit.source: Filters in Machine Learning Studio
trans-unit.target: Filters in Machine Learning Studio

trans-unit.source: Studio provides a variety of filtering methods.
trans-unit.target: Studio provides a variety of filtering methods.

trans-unit.source: All of the methods are widely used in machine learning and a variety of engineering disciplines.
trans-unit.target: All of the methods are widely used in machine learning and a variety of engineering disciplines.

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>Filters based on waveform decomposition</legacyBold>, such as finite impulse response (FIR) and infinite impulse response (IIR) filters.
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>Filters based on waveform decomposition</legacyBold>, such as finite impulse response (FIR) and infinite impulse response (IIR) filters.

trans-unit.source: These filters work by removing specific components from an overall series, which lets you view and investigate the simplified waveform.
trans-unit.target: These filters work by removing specific components from an overall series, which lets you view and investigate the simplified waveform.

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>Filters based on moving averages or median values</legacyBold>.
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>Filters based on moving averages or median values</legacyBold>.

trans-unit.source: These filters smooth out variations in a data series by averaging across windows of time.
trans-unit.target: These filters smooth out variations in a data series by averaging across windows of time.

trans-unit.source: The windows can be fixed or sliding, and they can have different shapes.
trans-unit.target: The windows can be fixed or sliding, and they can have different shapes.

trans-unit.source: For example, a triangular window peaks at the current data point (weights the current value stronger) and tails off before and after the data point (weights preceding and following values less strongly).
trans-unit.target: For example, a triangular window peaks at the current data point (weights the current value stronger) and tails off before and after the data point (weights preceding and following values less strongly).

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>User-defined or custom filters</legacyBold>.
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>User-defined or custom filters</legacyBold>.

trans-unit.source: If you already know the transformations that should be applied to a data series, you can create a user-defined filter and provide the numeric coefficients that are applied to transform the data series.
trans-unit.target: If you already know the transformations that should be applied to a data series, you can create a user-defined filter and provide the numeric coefficients that are applied to transform the data series.

trans-unit.source: A custom filter can emulate a FIR or IIR filter but you have more control over the values to apply at each point in the series.
trans-unit.target: A custom filter can emulate a FIR or IIR filter but you have more control over the values to apply at each point in the series.

trans-unit.source: Filter Terminology
trans-unit.target: Filter Terminology

trans-unit.source: The following are some simple definitions of terms that are used in the parameters and properties of filters.
trans-unit.target: The following are some simple definitions of terms that are used in the parameters and properties of filters.

trans-unit.source: In general, filtering is based on the principles of <newTerm>waveform analysis</newTerm>.
trans-unit.target: In general, filtering is based on the principles of <newTerm>waveform analysis</newTerm>.

trans-unit.source: You design a filter to suppress or amplify parts of the signal, to expose underlying trends, reduce noise and interference, or to identify data values that otherwise might not be perceived.
trans-unit.target: You design a filter to suppress or amplify parts of the signal, to expose underlying trends, reduce noise and interference, or to identify data values that otherwise might not be perceived.

trans-unit.source: Various techniques are applied to decompose the individual trends or waveform components that create the actual data values.
trans-unit.target: Various techniques are applied to decompose the individual trends or waveform components that create the actual data values.

trans-unit.source: The series of values (whether that is an econometric series or the composite frequencies of audio signals) can be analyzed by using trigonometric functions to identify and isolate individual wave forms.
trans-unit.target: The series of values (whether that is an econometric series or the composite frequencies of audio signals) can be analyzed by using trigonometric functions to identify and isolate individual wave forms.

trans-unit.source: Filters can then be applied to these wave forms to eliminate noise, amplify some waves, or remove targeted components.
trans-unit.target: Filters can then be applied to these wave forms to eliminate noise, amplify some waves, or remove targeted components.

trans-unit.source: When filtering is applied to a noisy series to isolate different components, you can specify which frequencies to remove or strengthen by specifying the band of frequencies to work with.
trans-unit.target: When filtering is applied to a noisy series to isolate different components, you can specify which frequencies to remove or strengthen by specifying the band of frequencies to work with.

trans-unit.source: Here is an overview of available frequencies and their related filters:
trans-unit.target: Here is an overview of available frequencies and their related filters:

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>Passband</legacyBold>: The range of frequencies that can pass through a filter without being attenuated or weakened.
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>Passband</legacyBold>: The range of frequencies that can pass through a filter without being attenuated or weakened.

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>Stopband</legacyBold>: A range of frequencies between specified limits, through which signals are not passed.
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>Stopband</legacyBold>: A range of frequencies between specified limits, through which signals are not passed.

trans-unit.source: You define the stopband by setting cut-off frequencies.
trans-unit.target: You define the stopband by setting cut-off frequencies.

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>High pass</legacyBold>: Let only high frequencies through.
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>High pass</legacyBold>: Let only high frequencies through.

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>Low pass</legacyBold>: Accept only frequencies below a specified cut-off value.
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>Low pass</legacyBold>: Accept only frequencies below a specified cut-off value.

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>Corner</legacyBold>: The corner frequency defines the boundary between the stopband and passband frequencies.
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>Corner</legacyBold>: The corner frequency defines the boundary between the stopband and passband frequencies.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you have the option to decide whether the corner is included in or excluded from the band.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you have the option to decide whether the corner is included in or excluded from the band.

trans-unit.source: A first-order filter causes gradual attenuation until the corner frequency and exponential attenuation after that.
trans-unit.target: A first-order filter causes gradual attenuation until the corner frequency and exponential attenuation after that.

trans-unit.source: Higher-order filters (such as Butterworth and Chebyshev filters) have steeper slopes after the corner frequency and attenuate the values in the stopband much more rapidly and fully.
trans-unit.target: Higher-order filters (such as Butterworth and Chebyshev filters) have steeper slopes after the corner frequency and attenuate the values in the stopband much more rapidly and fully.

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>Bandstop filter</legacyBold> (also called a <legacyBold>band reject</legacyBold> filter and a <legacyBold>notch</legacyBold> filter): Has only one stopband, which you define by specifying two frequencies: the high cut-off and low cut-off.
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>Bandstop filter</legacyBold> (also called a <legacyBold>band reject</legacyBold> filter and a <legacyBold>notch</legacyBold> filter): Has only one stopband, which you define by specifying two frequencies: the high cut-off and low cut-off.

trans-unit.source: A <legacyBold>bandpass</legacyBold> filter typically has two stopbands, one on either side of the desired component.
trans-unit.target: A <legacyBold>bandpass</legacyBold> filter typically has two stopbands, one on either side of the desired component.

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>Ripple</legacyBold>: A small unwanted variation that occurs periodically.
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>Ripple</legacyBold>: A small unwanted variation that occurs periodically.

trans-unit.source: In Azure Machine Learning, you can specify the amount of ripple to tolerate as part of the parameters in the IIR filter design.
trans-unit.target: In Azure Machine Learning, you can specify the amount of ripple to tolerate as part of the parameters in the IIR filter design.

trans-unit.source: Need more information?
trans-unit.target: Need more information?

trans-unit.source: If you are new to digital signal processing, this ham radio education site, <externalLink><linkText> An Introduction to Digital Signal Processing</linkText><linkUri>http://www.hamradioschool.com/an-introduction-to-digital-signal-processing-dsp/</linkUri></externalLink>, provides definitions and helpful visual aids covering basic terminology and concepts.
trans-unit.target: If you are new to digital signal processing, this ham radio education site, <externalLink><linkText> An Introduction to Digital Signal Processing</linkText><linkUri>http://www.hamradioschool.com/an-introduction-to-digital-signal-processing-dsp/</linkUri></externalLink>, provides definitions and helpful visual aids covering basic terminology and concepts.

trans-unit.source: List of Modules
trans-unit.target: List of Modules

trans-unit.source: The modules in the Filter category include:
trans-unit.target: The modules in the Filter category include:

trans-unit.source: Module
trans-unit.target: Module

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Applies a filter to specified columns of a dataset
trans-unit.target: Applies a filter to specified columns of a dataset

trans-unit.source: Creates a finite impulse response filter for signal processing
trans-unit.target: Creates a finite impulse response filter for signal processing

trans-unit.source: Creates an infinite impulse response filter for signal processing
trans-unit.target: Creates an infinite impulse response filter for signal processing

trans-unit.source: Creates a median filter used to smooth data for trend analysis
trans-unit.target: Creates a median filter used to smooth data for trend analysis

trans-unit.source: Creates a moving average filter that smooths data for trend analysis
trans-unit.target: Creates a moving average filter that smooths data for trend analysis

trans-unit.source: Creates a threshold filter that constrains values
trans-unit.target: Creates a threshold filter that constrains values

trans-unit.source: Creates a custom finite or infinite impulse response filter
trans-unit.target: Creates a custom finite or infinite impulse response filter
